ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Macroeconomic theory. General equilibrium theory, Solow model, etc
I learned a lot of math through macroeconomics. I learned to analyze a problem and put it into mathematical terms.

macroeconomics content: competitive general equilibrium, consumption smoothing, risk and uncertainty, dynamic general equilibrium, New Keynesian theory and monetary policy

extensive practice with multivariable calculus problems, algebraic manipulation, taking logarithms

 mental fortitude to stare at scary-looking equations, have your brain be puzzled initially, but over time come to understand and appreciate them

Its macro with math. No hand waving - you work through all of it rigorously. Thats what sets 126 apart from Econ 116 & 122. If you felt like intro Econ glossed over too many things, this class is for you.

The best part - though the material is rigorous, you end up getting many results that feel intuitive. Except now you know the intuition is legit because youve also worked through the derivation. Its a pretty great feeling to look back and realize Ive built an understanding of many important models, including dynamic equilibrium, consumption smoothing, and the Neo-Keynesian model.
This was a great course that connected macro ideas with the mathematics behind them.
I really enjoyed the content of the class. I enjoyed that we were able to explore econ through math.
Better understanding of macroeconomics through various models.
Macroeconomic models, some excel modeling

-Using data to apply and examine macroeconomic models
-Learning how to craft models which predict fundamental macroeconomic trends (i.e. change of consumption with interest rate)
-You will not necessarily learn how to create exact models in all cases, but rather begin the foundational steps that will create models which predict the direction of changes.
-Learn how to utilize math to solve first order conditions (large use of the Lagrangian, partial derivatives, natural logs to split apart equations, summations)
I learned how to apply theoretical models to real data.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Really compelling lectures, office hours are great, TF section is helpful and useful to understanding the course, psets are really good for understanding the material and realizing the applications of it to the real world.
The course was well structured and progressed from easier material to harder material.

In lecture, Zhen helped student learning by answering questions with a lot of care, asking "Did it make sense?" after his first explanation, and providing additional explanations if necessary. He and Ziqing were also very helpful in office hours, where most of the learning actually took place.

Overall the course felt disorganized. The textbook listed for the course was never once discussed (on the syllabus just for show). The course schedule was tentative and some topics were never covered. The lecture numbers in the files did not agree with the lecture numbers in the titles (i.e. Lecture 17 is Lecture 18). There was one lecture that was just two slides with a graph and a table of values without titles. The timing of the TF section, 7pm on Thursday, was decided by a one-vote margin in a poll at the beginning of the semester which included shoppers, and as a result only about 20-30% of the class ever showed up. I still showed up even though it was a terribly inconvenient time. Lecture slides and problem sets often had typos, which Zhen mentioned but never corrected. Communication of expectations for the course were unclear and I only really learned what this course is about (mathematical applications you learn from the TF sessions and office hours) after the midterm (but fortunately in time for the final).

Strengths: You get a super clear sense of structure. Zhen makes sure to explain the outline of what youll cover at the start of each lecture. 
Strong sense of interaction: since the class is about 20 people, the professor has the bandwidth to answer everyones questions in detail. You get way more interaction than Econ 122.

Weaknesses: problem set due date was a little awkward. They made it due at noon, but if it were due at midnight it wouldve been better.

I thought the class was well taught and the content was all very interesting. The professor and TA were also very hands on and willing to help. I  wish the class was a little more engaging at times and participation was more encouraged.

Strengths: Zhen Huo is an amazing professor, with extremely clear lecture explanations and office hours to improve our learning and assist. Exams were incredibly fair and tested knowledge. Weaknesses: Obviously, the material can get a bit dry at times, but I think Prof. Huo was great about bringing in data and making things relevant to the real world.
I think the strength of this course was a comprehensive introduction to most Macroeconomic Models. Additionally, I enjoyed being able to work with data from time to time.

Strengths:
-Psets, I think that the problem sets were very well formed, and helped me to learn the material a lot better. I think that the lectures were good for introducing the ideas, but psets were good for building true understanding. Sometimes they are difficult, but they prepare you well for exams. Redo problems before the midterm and final! The psets in the middle did get tedious for me, as I did not put enough time into them for understanding, but once I understood the Lagrangian, first order conditions, and summations well, the problems on the final were like butter, and were actually fun to complete.
-Section, I really thought that the sections were well done. Our teaching fellow, Ziqing, did a great job explaining homework problems (section was a day after homework was due), and this also helped to reinforce understanding of solutions, and the process to get there. 
-Lectures, I think that Professor Huo did a great job with example problems in lectures, which helped to guide you through the homework.
Weaknesses:
-I think that some of the middle lectures became a bit tedious, as they did not reflect homework problems. We had several lectures on side topics, like unemployment, like in the economy of France, which were interesting to learn about, but I feel that the math heavy lectures towards the end were a bit cramped as a result. Perhaps if these side lectures were placed at the end of the course, and the math heavy lectures were earlier, then students would have more time to cement their understanding of the math.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: ABSOLUTELY. BEST CLASS THIS SEMESTER. good. take. please.
Take this course if you want to be exposed to a lot of algebra. If you enjoy math, then you will enjoy this class.

Yes! Just know that this is basically an applied math course, and a bit disorganized, and the way you learn the material is by going to office hours and TF sessions with problem solving. The lectures are necessary but not sufficient.

Highly recommend for Econ&Math majors and Econ majors who want to understand macro well. The models you learn here will pop up again if you take higher level Econ classes, so its worth it to learn them well. If it's with Zhen, extra recommend!

If youre debating between this class and Econ 122, give 126 a chance. Go to one full Econ 126 lecture and youll be able to decide. But please dont choose 122 just because it sounds easier. Theres a chance youll actually enjoy the content in 126 as more than another requirement.
Yes! Great if you're interested in math and Econ and how they overlap

If you're deciding between ECON 122 and 126, absolutely take this class. I don't think it's much harder (and maybe even easier), from discussions with friends in intermediate macro. And, Prof. Huo is a gem, and you gain all of the benefits of being in a small class with more individualized attention.

Yes! If you are interested in the math behind the models or generally getting a more solid understanding of the material, I highly recommend this course over the regular intermediate macro option. Zhen is a fantastic and very very caring professor. And it is a wonderful opportunity to learn Econ in a small group.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in Macroeconomics. It is quite theoretical, but we also get to work with data and apply the models we learn to the real world.

I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in the applications of math to macroeconomics. It was really a joy towards the end of the semester; I love math, and it was great to see how it all began to work together with the macro theories. The math is a tad bit challenging to wrap your mind around at first, but is rewarding in the end.
YES! Super amazing class!
